template.name: AWS_Federated Amazon EKS cluster
template.desc:
Hybrid network connectivity from a data center to the AWS Cloud

The federated control pod is deployed as a regular pod into Kubernetes cluster. For high availability purposes, it is recommend to make the Amazon EKS cluster primary. 

Requirements REQ2 (data protection) and Customer-REQ1 (reliable connectivity) can be met using Architecture 1.1: Hybrid network connectivity from a data center to the AWS Cloud. 

Federation can be done through the kubefed project, which allows you to coordinate the configuration of multiple Kubernetes clusters from a single set of APIs in a hosting cluster.

weakness.name: CWE-15
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-15: External Control of System or Configuration Setting One or more system settings or configuration elements can be externally controlled by a user. Allowing external control of system settings can disrupt service or cause an application to behave in unexpected, and potentially malicious ways.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-300
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-300: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint. In order to establish secure communication between two parties, it is often important to adequately verify the identity of entities at each end of the communication channel. Inadequate or inconsistent verification may result in insufficient or incorrect identification of either communicating entity. This can have negative consequences such as misplaced trust in the entity at the other end of the channel. An attacker can leverage this by interposing between the communicating entities and masquerading as the original entity. In the absence of sufficient verification of identity, such an attacker can eavesdrop and potentially modify the communication between the original entities.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-540
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example, obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

weakness.name: CWE-942
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-942: Permissive Cross-domain Policy with Untrusted Domains The product uses a cross-domain policy file that includes domains that should not be trusted.

countermeasure.name: Automate secure configuration management
countermeasure.desc:
Eliminate manual errors and detect drift by managing every Direct Connect objectconnections, LAGs, virtual interfaces, gateway associationsthrough vetted infrastructure-as-code (IaC) pipelines and continuous compliance checks:

  1. define configurations in IaC
    • Use AWS CloudFormation, Terraform, or AWS CDK modules that encapsulate approved settings (BGP ASN ranges, VLAN IDs, Jumbo Frames, SiteLink = false).
    • Parameterize only what needs to vary (Region, speed); hard-code security defaults (e.g., enableSiteLink: false, mtu: 9001).
  2. enforce change control
    • Protect the IaC repo with branch protection, mandatory code-review, and automated security linting (cfn-nag, tfsec).
    • Require all Direct Connect changes to flow through the pipeline; block console or ad-hoc CLI edits with an Organizations SCP denying directconnect:* when aws:CalledViaLast cloudformation.amazonaws.com or your CI role.
  3. continuous drift detection
    • Turn on AWS Config rule directconnect-connection-config-check (custom) that compares live attributes to the IaC source of truth; mark resources NON_COMPLIANT on mismatch.
    • Trigger an EventBridge rule that opens a ticket or auto-reverts drift via an SSM automation document.
  4. version and audit
    • Tag every Direct Connect resource with the Git commit hash that provisioned it (IaCCommit=<sha>).
    • Store pipeline logs and change sets in an immutable S3 bucket for forensic review.

Automated, declarative management guarantees consistent security baselines, accelerates approved changes, and surfaces unauthorized modifications within minutes.

References

  • What is AWS Direct Connect?
  • What Is AWS Config?

countermeasure.name: Enforce IAM identity-based policies for AWS Direct Connect
countermeasure.desc:
Create narrowly scoped IAM policies (and, if you use AWS Organizations, complementary SCPs) so that only approved network-admin roles can perform Direct Connect management actionssuch as CreateConnection, AllocateHostedConnection, ConfirmPrivateVirtualInterface, or DeleteLag.

  • Author purpose-built roles give each network-engineering or automation role a custom policy that allows only the Direct Connect APIs it truly needs and only in approved Regions or on resources tagged Environment=prod. Example snippet:
  • {
     "Effect": "Allow",
     "Action": [
       "directconnect:CreateConnection",
       "directconnect:DeleteConnection",
       "directconnect:Describe*"
     ],
     "Resource": "*",
     "Condition": {
       "StringEquals": { "aws:RequestedRegion": [ "us-east-1", "eu-west-1" ] },
       "ForAllValues:StringEquals": { "aws:ResourceTag/NetworkOwner": "net-ops" }
     }
    }
  • Block everyone else attach an SCP that denies directconnect:* unless the principal ARN matches the network-admin roles or the AWS SSO group you designate.
  • Require MFA for sensitive calls add an IAM condition BoolIfExists/aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent : true so console users must present MFA when modifying connections or virtual interfaces.
  • Monitor and audit stream CloudTrail events that match directconnect:* to CloudWatch Logs and set an EventBridge rule to alert on any caller outside your allow-list.
  • Review quarterly export IAM Access Analyzer last used data and remove unused Direct Connect permissions; update Region and tag conditions as your footprint changes.

Enforcing identity-based, least-privilege policies prevents unauthorized creation, deletion, or tampering of Direct Connect links that could disrupt hybrid connectivity.

References

  • What is AWS Direct Connect?

countermeasure.name: Implement BGP hijacking protections
countermeasure.desc:
Protect Direct Connect virtual interfaces from BGP hijacking and route leaks by configuring both ends of the peering sessionyour on-prem router and AWSto accept only authenticated, pre-agreed prefixes and AS paths:

  1. enable BGP MD5 authentication
    • When you create or update the private or transit virtual interface, specify a BGP MD5 key (Amazon console Add BGP password).
    • Configure the matching password <secret> on your customer router so unauthenticated sessions are rejected.
  2. advertise and accept explicit prefix lists
    • On your router, use a prefix-list / route-map that only advertises the exact CIDR blocks you own (no more-specifics, no 0.0.0.0/0).
    • Apply an inbound filter that accepts only the AWS-announced RFC 1918 ranges (or any public space you expect) to prevent a poisoned route table.
  3. set max-prefix & as-path filters
    • neighbor <aws-peering-ip> maximum-prefix <N> restart 5pick N slightly above the number of prefixes you legitimately expect (e.g., 5 % head-room).
    • Deny inbound prefixes whose AS_PATH is not exactly AS16509 (AWS) or the sequence you anticipate for a hosted connection.
  4. enable BFD and low hold timers
    • Turn on Bidirectional Forwarding Detection (BFD) and set aggressive timers (e.g., 300 ms, 3 multiplier) so hijacked or flapping sessions drop quickly.
    • If your device lacks BFD, reduce BGP keep-alive/hold timers (30 / 90 s) instead of the defaults.
  5. monitor and alert
    • Stream Direct Connect BGP state change and RouteChange CloudWatch metrics; alarm on BGPPeerDown, MaxPrefixesExceeded, or unexpected ASN/path events.
    • Log all BGP syslog messages on the customer router to a SIEM and detect new or more-specific routes instantly.
  6. review quarterly
    • Compare advertised prefixes against your IPAM source of truth; prune any stale routes.
    • Rotate the BGP MD5 key when staff leave or devices are replaced.

These layered controlsauthentication, strict prefix/as-path filtering, and rapid failure detectiongreatly reduce the chance that an attacker can hijack your Direct Connect traffic or inject malicious routes.

References

  • AWS Direct Connect routing policies and BGP communities

countermeasure.name: Monitor and safeguard BGP routes
countermeasure.desc:
Continuously watch every Direct Connect BGP session and automatically flagor shut downany route change that could steer traffic to an unexpected destination.

  1. Stream BGP telemetry to CloudWatch
    • Enable the Direct Connect metrics BgpPeerState, BgpRouteFlapDampening, and BGPMaxPrefixesExceeded.
    • Create CloudWatch alarms that fire when a peer drops (BgpPeerState = 3), the route count jumps beyond the configured max-prefix value, or flapping exceeds a defined threshold.
  2. Log all route advertisements
    • On the customer router, export BGP UPDATE messages to a syslog or NetFlow collector; forward to your SIEM for real-time correlation.
    • Retain logs for at least 90 days so you can trace when and how a suspicious prefix entered the table.
  3. Detect drift with AWS Config & EventBridge
    • Deploy a custom AWS Config rule that compares the live list of accepted/advertised prefixes against your approved prefix list in IPAM.
    • When Config marks a resource NON_COMPLIANT, trigger an EventBridge rule that pages on-call staff andoptionallyruns an SSM Automation document to disable the virtual interface until reviewed.
  4. Implement route sanity checks
    • Use the routers prefix-list + route-map to drop any prefix longer than /24 or outside your owned CIDR blocks.
    • Set neighbor <peer-ip> maximum-prefix <N> restart 5 to halt a session that suddenly advertises too many routes.
  5. Visualise and review
    • Build a CloudWatch dashboard that shows current prefix count, peer state, and alarm status for every virtual interface.
    • Review logs and metrics weekly; investigate any new ASN in the AS-PATH or unexplained rise in prefix count.

Proactive monitoring combined with automatic drift detection stops hijacked, leaked, or mis-typed routes before they impact production traffic.

References

  • Monitoring Direct Connect BGP sessions with CloudWatch metrics
  • AWS Direct Connect routing policies and BGP communities

countermeasure.name: Regularly audit Direct Connect configurations
countermeasure.desc:
At least once per quarterand after every network changegenerate and review a complete inventory of Direct Connect resources (connections, LAGs, virtual interfaces, gateway associations, route filters, and BGP settings). Compare the live state against your infrastructure-as-code definitions and security baseline, then remediate drift immediately.

Implementation guidance

  1. Automate the snapshot
    • Run aws directconnect describe-* commands (or Terraform / CloudFormation drift-detect) from a scheduled pipeline; export JSON to an S3 bucket versioned for audit.
  2. Evaluate with AWS Config & Security Hub
    • Enable custom and managed Config rulesfor example, flag connections without BGP MD5 keys or VIFs without route filters. Send findings to Security Hub so they appear on your compliance dashboard.
  3. Cross-check critical attributes
    • Verify port speed, LOA expiry, VLAN IDs, SiteLink status, BGP ASN, maximum-prefix limits, and MD5 keys against your approved standards document or IPAM system.
  4. Document and remediate
    • Publish an audit report listing compliant items, drift, and required fixes. Track remediation tasks in your ticket system and confirm closure before the next audit cycle.

Regular, tool-driven audits prevent silent mis-configurations that could break redundancy, expose routes, or violate compliance requirements.

References

countermeasure.name: Use PFS-supported cipher suites
countermeasure.desc:
Whether youre calling the AWS APIs that manage Direct Connect or encrypting application payloads that traverse the circuit (for example, TLS to private NLBs or HTTPS to AWS service endpoints), configure the TLS stack so it negotiates only cipher suites that provide Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS)that is, suites that use an ephemeral Diffie-Hellman key exchange such as ECDHE or DHE.

Implementation guidance

  1. restrict the client cipher list
    • On routers, firewalls, and application servers that initiate TLS sessions over Direct Connect, remove all static-key suites (RSA key exchange) and legacy ciphers (3DES, RC4).
    • Keep the list to modern suites such as TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256, TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384, or (preferably) TLS 1.3 defaults.
  2. enforce on inbound endpoints
    • For load balancers and APIs hosted in AWS, select an ELB security policy that requires TLS 1.2/1.3 with PFS (for example ELBSecurityPolicy-TLS13-1-2-Res-2021-06).
    • Reject client hellos that offer only non-PFS suites.
  3. verify with automated scans
    • Use openssl s_client -cipher 'aNULL' -connect host:443 and expect no handshake.
    • Schedule weekly or monthly scans (SSLLabs, AWS Inspector network assessments) to confirm no regressions.
  4. monitor for legacy fall-back
    • Enable CloudTrail data-events for ELB and look for TLSNegotiationError.
    • Set CloudWatch alarms on a spike in cipher-mismatch metricsan early sign that a client or server reverted to weak crypto.

PFS ensures that, even if a long-term private key is later compromised, past TLS sessions cannot be decryptedan essential property for protecting high-value traffic flowing over dedicated circuits like AWS Direct Connect.

References

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data interception
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data interception involves unauthorized parties gaining access to data as it is being transmitted over the network. This threat compromises the confidentiality and integrity of data sent via AWS Direct Connect, potentially leading to data breaches and unauthorized access to sensitive information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, and state-sponsored actors. Attack vectors include man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, compromised network devices, and physical tapping of communication lines.

Impacts

Data interception can result in confidentiality breaches, data integrity compromise, operational disruption, reputational damage, and financial loss.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker intercepts communication between an on-premises network and AWS by positioning themselves between the endpoints, allowing them to eavesdrop or inject malicious data into the communication stream.

threat.name: Unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access refers to individuals gaining access to AWS Direct Connect resources without proper authorization. This can occur due to weak access controls, compromised credentials, or configuration errors, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized manipulation of resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, and attackers exploiting compromised credentials. Attack vectors include stolen or weak passwords, misconfigured IAM policies, and exploitation of insufficiently restricted network access.

Impacts

Unauthorized access can result in data breaches, loss of sensitive information, unauthorized changes to configurations, financial loss, and reputational damage. It compromises the integrity and confidentiality of the AWS environment.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker gains access to AWS Direct Connect resources by exploiting weak or stolen credentials, allowing them to view or manipulate sensitive data. Another scenario involves a misconfigured IAM policy that inadvertently grants excessive permissions to a user, leading to unauthorized actions within the AWS environment.

threat.name: Insecure configuration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure configuration involves improper setup of AWS Direct Connect resources, leading to potential vulnerabilities. Misconfigurations can result from errors in security settings, inadequate access controls, or failure to follow best practices, exposing the infrastructure to various threats.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include system administrators, attackers exploiting configuration errors, and automated tools scanning for vulnerabilities. Attack vectors include misconfigured access controls, incorrect security group settings, and failure to apply updates or patches.

Impacts

Insecure configurations can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential exploitation of vulnerable systems. These issues can compromise the security and integrity of data and services.

Example Attack Scenarios

An administrator mistakenly configures overly permissive access controls, allowing unauthorized users to access sensitive data through AWS Direct Connect. Another scenario involves outdated security settings that an attacker exploits to gain unauthorized access, leading to data breaches and service disruptions.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: BGP hijacking
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

BGP hijacking involves malicious actors rerouting internet traffic by corrupting the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) routing tables. This allows attackers to intercept, monitor, or manipulate data intended for legitimate network paths, potentially impacting AWS Direct Connect's communication routes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, state-sponsored actors, and rogue network operators. Attack vectors involve manipulating BGP announcements to falsely advertise ownership of IP prefixes, causing traffic to be misrouted through the attackers network.

Impacts

BGP hijacking can lead to data interception, traffic analysis, disruption of services, loss of data integrity, and potential data breaches. It can cause significant operational disruptions and loss of trust in network security.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker corrupts BGP routing tables to divert traffic from a corporate network to their own servers, allowing them to capture sensitive information transmitted via AWS Direct Connect. Another scenario involves an attacker using a compromised or rogue router to announce false BGP routes, disrupting service availability and causing a loss of connectivity for critical applications.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-315
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-315: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information in a Cookie The product stores sensitive information in cleartext in a cookie. Attackers can use widely-available tools to view the cookie and read the sensitive information. Even if the information is encoded in a way that is not human-readable, certain techniques could determine which encoding is being used, then decode the information.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-384
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-384: Session Fixation Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

weakness.name: CWE-404
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-404: Improper Resource Shutdown or Release The product does not release or incorrectly releases a resource before it is made available for re-use. When a resource is created or allocated, the developer is responsible for properly releasing the resource as well as accounting for all potential paths of expiration or invalidation, such as a set period of time or revocation.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-664
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-664: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime The product does not maintain or incorrectly maintains control over a resource throughout its lifetime of creation, use, and release.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-862
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-862: Missing Authorization The product does not perform an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Enforce minimal privilege security group rules
countermeasure.desc: To minimize vulnerabilities in AWS EC2 environments, configure security groups with the least permissive rules necessary for operational functionality. Start by defining default deny-all inbound and outbound rules, and then explicitly allow only the required traffic based on the application's needs. Regularly review and update these rules to adapt to changing network requirements and to close any gaps that may arise due to evolving threat landscapes. This approach ensures a strict security posture by limiting potential entry points for attackers.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Resource mismanagement
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Resource mismanagement in AWS EC2 encompasses the improper allocation, oversight, and operation of EC2 resources. This can include inefficient use of computing power, storage, and network configurations, leading to increased costs and reduced system performance.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Primary agents include internal misconfigurations, lack of resource oversight, and inadequate scaling strategies which may fail to meet system demands or optimize costs effectively.

Impacts

Consequences of resource mismanagement can include overspending, performance bottlenecks, and potential service interruptions, all of which can negatively affect the operational efficiency and economic viability of the system.

Example Attack Scenarios

A typical scenario might involve an organization that has over-provisioned EC2 instances without proper load balancing or auto-scaling configurations. This results in high operational costs and underutilized resources, impacting the budget and overall system efficiency.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Failover and recovery issues
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Failover and recovery issues in AWS EC2 pertain to the challenges and failures that can arise during the process of recovering from hardware or software failures. Proper management is crucial to ensure continuous availability and data integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main agents include system malfunctions, configuration errors, and external disruptions that impact the EC2 environment. These can be exacerbated by inadequate redundancy planning or flawed recovery procedures.

Impacts

Ineffective failover and recovery strategies can lead to significant service disruptions, data loss, and prolonged downtime, affecting business operations and trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

A scenario could involve an EC2 instance failing to switch over to a standby in another Availability Zone due to misconfigured failover processes. This results in an outage, where critical applications remain offline until manual intervention is performed, leading to potential data loss and service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate access controls
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Inadequate access controls in AWS EC2 involve insufficient management of permissions and access rights to EC2 resources, which can expose sensitive data and computing processes to unauthorized users or malicious entities.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include unauthorized users who may exploit weak authentication and authorization processes to gain access to EC2 instances. Misconfigured IAM roles and security group settings are common vectors.

Impacts

The consequences can range from data breaches and unauthorized system modifications to complete system takeover, compromising data integrity and organizational security.

Example Attack Scenarios

An example scenario could involve an attacker exploiting overly permissive IAM role configurations to access and manipulate EC2 instances. This unauthorized access could lead to data leakage, system disruptions, or the deployment of malicious software within the network.

threat.name: System vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

System Vulnerabilities in AWS EC2 refer to weaknesses in the EC2 infrastructure that can be exploited by attackers. These vulnerabilities may stem from outdated software, misconfigured systems, or inherent security flaws.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers and malicious insiders who exploit these vulnerabilities through malware, social engineering, or direct system attacks.

Impacts

The impacts of system vulnerabilities can be severe, including unauthorized data access, system downtime, and compromised data integrity and confidentiality.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker discovers an unpatched vulnerability in an EC2 instances operating system. They exploit this flaw to gain unauthorized access and install ransomware, leading to data encryption and a demand for payment to restore access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1133 - External Remote Services

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data breach and loss
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data Breach and Loss in AWS EC2 encompasses unauthorized access and unintended exposure or destruction of data stored on EC2 instances. These incidents can occur due to a variety of security lapses or system failures.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include hackers exploiting security vulnerabilities, insiders abusing their access rights, or accidental exposures due to misconfigurations. Common vectors are compromised credentials, malware, or poorly secured API endpoints.

Impacts

Impacts range from the loss of sensitive or proprietary information to regulatory non-compliance and reputational damage, which can result in significant financial costs.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker uses stolen credentials to access an EC2 instance and exfiltrates databases containing personal customer information, resulting in a data breach that violates privacy laws and leads to financial penalties and loss of customer trust.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

threat.name: Network security issues
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Network security issues in AWS EC2 involve vulnerabilities that affect the network layer, exposing EC2 instances to unauthorized access or data interception. These can result from improper security configurations, weak network protocols, or inadequate encryption practices.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Common agents include external attackers and malicious insiders utilizing tools like packet sniffers, man-in-the-middle attacks, or exploiting public-facing APIs.

Impacts

The impacts include data theft, compromised system integrity, and potential service disruptions, leading to operational and financial losses.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker performs a man-in-the-middle attack on unencrypted network communication between EC2 instances, capturing sensitive data transmitted over the network. This breach could result in significant data leakage, including customer information or proprietary business data.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Choose Amazon EKS Managed Node Groups, which are maintained by Amazon for enhanced security
countermeasure.desc:
Amazon EKS managed node groups provide automated infrastructure management, ensuring nodes are always running the latest Amazon EKS-optimized AMIs with the latest security patches. By using Amazon EKS managed node groups, you can reduce the operational burden on your team and enhance the security posture of your Kubernetes clusters.

To implement this control:

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console.
  2. Open the Amazon EKS console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/eks.
  3. Select the cluster where you want to create a managed node group.
  4. In the left navigation pane, choose Compute, then select Add node group.
  5. Follow the wizard to specify details for your managed node group, such as node group name, AMI type, instance type, and scaling configuration.
  6. Ensure the latest Amazon EKS-optimized AMI is selected to benefit from the latest security patches automatically managed by Amazon.
  7. Review the settings and create the managed node group.

Refer to the AWS official documentation for managed node groups for detailed instructions: Managed Node Groups.

For more insights into securing your EKS cluster, refer to the Amazon EKS Security Best Practices document.

countermeasure.name: Implement Amazon EKS managed policies for restricted access
countermeasure.desc:
To maintain a secure Amazon EKS (Elastic Kubernetes Service) environment, it is crucial to implement managed policies that restrict access to the master cluster resources based on the principle of least privilege. Amazon EKS provides managed policies facilitating this security requirement.

Follow the steps below to apply these managed policies:

  1. Identify Required Permissions: Begin by identifying the specific permissions required for each user or role interacting with the EKS cluster. Managed policies like AmazonEKSClusterPolicy and AmazonEKSServicePolicy provide a predefined set of permissions tailored for EKS operations. Refer to the AWS EKS Security Docs for more details.
  2. Create IAM Roles or Users: Create IAM roles or users that will interact with your EKS cluster. Ensure that you assign only the necessary permissions to each role or user to adhere to the least privilege principle.
  3. Attach Managed Policies: Attach the relevant managed policies to the IAM roles or users created. Use the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or AWS SDKs to perform the attachment. Heres an example CLI command to attach a managed policy to an existing role:aws iam attach-role-policy --role-name YOUR_ROLE_NAME --policy-arn arn:aws:iam::aws:policy/AmazonEKSClusterPolicy
  4. Validate and Test: Once the managed policies are applied, validate and test to ensure appropriate access restrictions are in place. Monitor access logs and IAM policies to confirm that the least privilege access is enforced.

By following these guidelines and utilizing Amazon EKS managed policies, you can effectively secure your master cluster resources while maintaining necessary operational functionalities.

References: AWS EKS Security Documentation

countermeasure.desc:
Implementing IAM roles and policies is a critical measure to ensure that only authorized users and services have access to the Kubernetes API server in your Amazon EKS Cluster. This countermeasure helps enforce the principle of least privilege, reducing the risk of unauthorized access and potential security breaches. Below is a step-by-step guide to implement this security control based on the official AWS security guidelines:

  1. Create IAM Policies:
    Create specific IAM policies that define the permissions required to access and interact with the Kubernetes API server. Ensure these policies adhere strictly to the least privilege principle.

  2. Associate IAM Policies with IAM Roles:
    Create IAM roles that will be used by users and applications requiring access to the API server. Attach the previously created IAM policies to these roles.
  3. Map IAM Roles to Kubernetes RBAC:

  4. Periodically Review IAM Policies and Roles:
    Regularly audit and review IAM policies and roles to ensure that they still adhere to the least privilege principle and update them as necessary to accommodate any changes in your security requirements. For additional details, refer to the IAM Policies User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Implement Pod Security Standards (PSS) to manage security-sensitive elements of the pod specification
countermeasure.desc:
Pod Security Standards (PSS) provide a framework for managing security-sensitive aspects of pod specifications, ensuring consistent, scalable, and secure configurations for workloads in your Amazon EKS clusters. By implementing PSS, cloud engineers can enforce Kubernetes-native security profiles (Privileged, Baseline, Restricted) to protect workloads from misconfigurations and potential vulnerabilities.

Amazon EKS fully supports the adoption of PSS as the recommended alternative to legacy Pod Security Policies (PSPs), aligning with Kubernetes security best practices and enabling streamlined pod security management.

Actionable Steps to Implement PSS

Understand the PSS Profiles:

  • Privileged: Suitable for workloads requiring minimal restrictions.
  • Baseline: A standard for most workloads, ensuring no overly permissive configurations.
  • Restricted: The most secure profile, adhering to the principle of least privilege.

Enable Pod Security Admission Controllers:

  • Utilize the Kubernetes Admission Controller to enforce PSS profiles at runtime.
  • Configure the appropriate profile for each namespace, aligning with workload security requirements.

Integrate PSS Enforcement with CI/CD Pipelines:

  • Update your CI/CD pipelines to validate Kubernetes manifests against PSS profiles during the build process.
  • Use tools like kubectl or third-party validators to ensure compliance with PSS policies before deployment.

Monitor Policy Violations:

  • Enable Kubernetes audit logging to monitor and report policy violations.
  • Integrate AWS CloudWatch or other logging solutions for real-time visibility into policy enforcement and violations.

Iterate and Evolve Policies:

  • Regularly review and update the assigned PSS profiles to align with evolving security needs and compliance standards.
  • Conduct periodic security audits to ensure workloads remain compliant with PSS policies.

Benefits of Implementing PSS

  • Standardization: PSS ensures consistent application of security policies across all workloads.
  • Scalability: Profiles can be applied and enforced at the namespace level, reducing administrative overhead.
  • Compliance: Aligns with Kubernetes direction, ensuring compatibility and reducing operational risk.

For additional guidance, refer to:

  • AWS EKS Documentation: Pod Security Standards
  • AWS Blog: Implementing Pod Security Standards in Amazon EKS
  • AWS FAQ: Pod Security Policy Removal

countermeasure.name: Migrate from Legacy Pod Security Policies (PSP)
countermeasure.desc:
Transitioning from legacy Pod Security Policies (PSPs) to modern alternatives is a critical step to strengthen the security posture of your AWS EKS clusters. PSPs, now deprecated and set for removal, are no longer a viable long-term solution for restricting pod behavior. Instead, AWS recommends adopting Kubernetes' Pod Security Standards (PSS), which provide a more robust and standardized framework for securing workloads.

Actionable Steps:

Audit Current PSP Usage:

  • Identify any existing PSP configurations in your cluster by reviewing your Kubernetes manifests and role-based access control (RBAC) bindings.
  • Use tools like kubectl to list active PSPs and associated workloads.

Plan Migration to PSS:

  • Familiarize yourself with the three profiles offered by PSS: Privileged, Baseline, and Restricted. These profiles correspond to varying levels of security restrictions.
  • Map your current PSP configurations to the equivalent PSS profiles by analyzing workload requirements and security objectives.

Implement Pod Security Admission Controllers:

  • Enable the Kubernetes Admission Controller for Pod Security in your EKS clusters to enforce PSS profiles during workload deployments.
  • Update CI/CD pipelines to validate manifests against PSS standards pre-deployment.

Test and Validate:

  • Deploy workloads with the new PSS profiles applied to ensure compatibility and minimal disruption.
  • Monitor for policy violations using Kubernetes audit logs or integrate with AWS CloudWatch for visibility.

Document and Maintain Compliance:

  • Maintain documentation on adopted profiles and their mapping to workloads.
  • Regularly review and update PSS policies to align with changing security and compliance requirements.

Why Migrate?

AWS EKS has officially deprecated PSPs, and they are slated for removal from Kubernetes versions 1.25 onwards. Continuing to rely on PSPs exposes your clusters to future compatibility issues and potential vulnerabilities. The migration to PSS ensures that your cluster remains secure, compliant, and up to date with Kubernetes best practices.

For detailed guidance on PSP removal and alternatives, consult the AWS FAQ on Pod Security Policy Removal.

Additional Resources:

  • AWS Documentation: Pod Security Policy
  • AWS Blog: Implementing Pod Security Standards in Amazon EKS

countermeasure.name: Regularly update and patch your node
countermeasure.desc:
Regularly updating and patching your EKS nodes is crucial to protect against vulnerabilities and security threats. To effectively implement this, follow these steps:

  1. Regularly monitor AWS security bulletins and the AWS Security Bulletins page to stay informed about the latest patches and updates.
  2. Use the Amazon EKS optimized AMIs (Amazon Machine Images) which are specifically designed and regularly updated by AWS to include the latest security patches.
  3. Configure a maintenance window for your clusters, where you can safely update and patch node groups without affecting the applications availability.
  4. Automate patch management by utilizing services such as AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager to manage and deploy patches across your EKS nodes.
  5. Consider using managed node groups which facilitate easy updates and maintenance by AWS, reducing the operational burden on your team.
  6. Regularly rotate and replace old nodes to ensure they are running the latest patched versions of AMIs.
  7. Integrate continuous monitoring tools to regularly check the status and version of your nodes, ensuring they remain compliant with security best practices.

For detailed guidelines, refer to the AWS EKS Security Best Practices documentation.

countermeasure.name: Set up Kubernetes network policies to manage traffic flow between pods
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing Kubernetes network policies within AWS EKS enhances the security posture of your cluster by regulating the traffic flow between pods, ensuring that only authorized communication paths are permitted. Below are the steps a cloud engineer should follow to configure these policies:

Enable Network Policies: AWS EKS supports network policies via the Calico plugin. It is essential to ensure that the EKS cluster is set up with network policy support. Refer to the EKS official documentation on Calico Network Policies to enable this feature.

Define Network Policies: Create NetworkPolicy resources to specify how groups of pods are allowed to communicate with each other and other network endpoints. The policies can specify allowed ingress and egress traffic. Here is an example of a network policy YAML file:

  1.        apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1    kind: NetworkPolicy    metadata:      name: allow-specific-service      namespace: your-namespace    spec:      podSelector:        matchLabels:          role: your-app      policyTypes:      - Ingress      - Egress      ingress:      - from:        - ipBlock:            cidr: 192.168.0.0/16      egress:      - to:        - ipBlock:            cidr: 100.64.0.0/10        

Apply the Network Policies: Use kubectl to apply the NetworkPolicy resource to your cluster:

  1. kubectl apply -f your-network-policy.yaml

Test the Configuration: Once the network policies are applied, it is crucial to test them to validate that the traffic flow is as expected. You can use network testing tools or custom scripts for validation.

Following these steps helps ensure that your EKS cluster leverages network policies effectively, enhancing its security. For more detailed information, refer to the AWS EKS Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS Secrets Manager to store and manage secrets
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard sensitive information within AWS EKS, it is crucial to store and manage secrets effectively using AWS Secrets Manager. This service enables you to securely store and manage access to secrets such as database credentials, API keys, and other confidential data.

Implementation Guidance

  1. Create a Secret in AWS Secrets Manager: Use the AWS Secrets Manager console, AWS CLI, or SDK to create a new secret. Follow the steps provided in the AWS Secrets Manager User Guide to set up your secrets correctly.
  2. IAM Policy Configuration: Configure Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies to control access to the secrets. Ensure that only authorized roles and users have permission to read or manage secrets. Detailed policies can be implemented as outlined in the AWS EKS Security Documentation.
  3. Integrate with Kubernetes: Use Kubernetes Secrets to integrate with AWS Secrets Manager. Create an ExternalSecrets resource that references the secrets stored in AWS Secrets Manager. This can be done using tools like the AWS Secrets and Configuration Provider (ASCP) for Kubernetes.
  4. Monitor and Rotate Secrets: Regularly monitor the usage of secrets and implement automatic rotation policies for enhanced security. AWS Secrets Manager supports automatic rotation of secrets, which can be configured as detailed in the Secrets Manager Rotation Guide.

By following these steps, you can leverage AWS Secrets Manager to securely manage sensitive information in your AWS EKS environments. For more detailed guidance, refer to the official AWS EKS Security Documentation.

usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Outdated Pod Security Policies
threat.desc:
General threat description
Use of deprecated or improperly configured Pod Security Policies (PSP) can result in leaving workloads vulnerable, facilitating unauthorized access and privilege escalation.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders or external attackers who exploit misconfigured or deprecated PSPs to gain unauthorized access or elevate privileges within a Kubernetes environment.
Impacts
Compromise of sensitive data, unauthorized control over Kubernetes workloads, and potential disruption of services.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies a deprecated PSP setup and uses it to bypass security controls, gaining administrative access to containers and escalating their privileges across the cluster, potentially accessing confidential information.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Cluster access control issues
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper access control can allow unauthorized users to interact with the Kubernetes cluster, leading to potential compromise and data leaks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders or external attackers exploiting weak authentication mechanisms, misconfigured IAM (Identity and Access Management) roles, or overly permissive access policies. Attack vectors could involve gaining access to Kubernetes API servers, exploiting unsecured endpoints, or leveraging compromised credentials to interact with the cluster.
Impacts
The impacts of unauthorized access to a Kubernetes cluster can be severe, including unauthorized data access, service disruptions, deployment of malicious containers, and potential breaching of customer data. The compromised environment could also be used to launch attacks on other systems within the same network.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker finds an exposed Kubernetes API server with weak authentication and gains full administrative access to the cluster. 2. A malicious insider abuses overly permissive IAM roles to deploy a malicious container image that exfiltrates sensitive data from the cluster. 3. Compromised credentials obtained through phishing are used to bypass access controls, allowing the attacker to tamper with configurations and disrupt services running on the cluster.

threat.name: Exposure of secrets and environment variables
threat.desc:
General threat description
Storing sensitive information like credentials and tokens in pods without proper encryption can lead to unauthorized access, compromising the security of your Kubernetes environment.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized individuals who gain access to the pod can easily extract sensitive information if it is stored in plain text. This could happen through compromised accounts, malware, or insider threats.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to critical resources, data breaches, potential financial losses, and harm to the organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a pod and finds unencrypted credentials stored in environment variables or configuration files. They use these credentials to access databases, APIs, or other services, leading to data exfiltration and operational disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores

threat.name: Inadequate network policies
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of defined network policies can allow unrestricted communication between pods, leading to potential security risks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors who gain access to a compromised pod can potentially move laterally within the Kubernetes cluster without restriction.
Impacts
This can lead to unauthorized access to sensitive data, compromise of multiple services, and the spread of malicious activity throughout the cluster.
Example Attack Scenarios
A compromised pod could be used as a foothold to access and exfiltrate data from other pods, escalate privileges, or disrupt services by leveraging the lack of restrictive network policies.

threat.name: Compromised nodes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Compromised nodes can have a broad impact on the entire Kubernetes environment by potentially facilitating unauthorized access, data leakage, and increasing cluster management risks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Adversaries can exploit vulnerabilities in the Kubernetes nodes, deploy malicious containers, or misuse node-level permissions to gain control over the nodes. This may be initiated through insecure APIs, exploited software vulnerabilities, or weak authentication mechanisms.
Impacts
The impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, disruption of service, loss of data integrity, and potential takeover of the entire cluster, which could lead to downtime and significant security breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker exploits a zero-day vulnerability in the container runtime on a Kubernetes node, gaining root access, and subsequently exfiltrates sensitive data stored in the node. 2. Using stolen node credentials, an attacker deploys a malicious container that scans and exploits other nodes in the cluster, increasing their control and compromising additional resources. 3. A security misconfiguration allows an adversary to execute arbitrary commands on a node, leading to data manipulation and unauthorized access to inter-node communication.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Lack of standardized Pod Security
threat.desc:
General threat description
The absence of standardized security practices can lead to vulnerabilities in AWS EKS configurations, potentially resulting in unauthorized access or manipulation of pod integrity and violations of security compliance. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit misconfigurations or weak security settings in the EKS environment to gain unauthorized access to Kubernetes pods or interfere with their operations. 
Impacts
Compromised pod integrity can lead to data breaches, service disruptions, and failure to meet compliance requirements, which can harm organizational reputation and result in financial losses. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers that role-based access controls (RBAC) are improperly configured, allowing unauthorized users to escalate privileges and modify running pods. Another scenario could involve an attacker exploiting the lack of network policies to perform a lateral movement attack between pods, accessing sensitive information across the cluster.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-914
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-914: Improper Control of Dynamically-Identified Variables The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-identified variables. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to access arbitrary variables that are specified by an input string. While these features can offer significant flexibility and reduce development time, they can be extremely dangerous if attackers can modify unintended variables that have security implications.

countermeasure.name: Enable CloudWatch Container Insights for Fargate tasks
countermeasure.desc:
Enable Amazon CloudWatch Container Insights to monitor the performance and health of your AWS Fargate tasks. This provides real-time visibility into container metrics, resource utilization, and operational health, facilitating prompt detection and response to issues.

Enable CloudWatch Container Insights:

  • Enable Container Insights in the ECS console or using AWS CLI.

Configure Metrics and Logs:

  • Set up metrics and log collection for CPU, memory, disk I/O, and network traffic.

Create Alarms and Dashboards:

  • Establish alarms for critical metrics and create dashboards for data visualization.

Regular Review:

  • Regularly review and update monitoring configurations based on performance data and requirements.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt ephemeral storage for Fargate tasks with AWS KMS
countermeasure.desc:
Use AWS Key Management Service (KMS) to encrypt ephemeral storage for AWS Fargate tasks. This ensures that all data at rest is protected from unauthorized access, maintaining the confidentiality and integrity of sensitive information.

Enable AWS KMS Encryption:

  • Configure your Fargate tasks to use AWS KMS for encrypting ephemeral storage.

Specify Encryption Keys:

  • Use customer-managed keys (CMKs) in AWS KMS to control and manage the encryption keys used for encrypting ephemeral storage.

Apply Encryption Policies:

  • Ensure appropriate IAM policies and KMS key policies are in place to restrict access to the encryption keys to authorized users and services only.

Monitor Encryption Status:

  • Regularly audit and monitor the encryption status and access logs through AWS CloudTrail and AWS KMS to ensure compliance and security.

countermeasure.name: Ensure isolated infrastructure for each Fargate task
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that each AWS Fargate task runs on isolated infrastructure to prevent resource sharing and mitigate potential security risks. This enhances security by ensuring that tasks do not interfere with each other and reduces the risk of resource contention and unauthorized access.

Use Dedicated VPCs:

  • Deploy Fargate tasks in dedicated Virtual Private Clouds (VPCs) to isolate network traffic and ensure tasks are separated from other resources.

Configure Security Groups:

  • Use security groups to control and isolate network traffic between Fargate tasks. Ensure that security groups are configured to allow only necessary communication and block all other traffic.

Set Up Task-Level Permissions:

  • Apply task-level IAM roles and policies to ensure each Fargate task has only the permissions it needs to operate, minimizing the risk of unauthorized access.

Monitor Resource Usage:

  • Implement monitoring and logging to track resource usage and performance of individual Fargate tasks. Use Amazon CloudWatch to detect anomalies and ensure that tasks do not interfere with each other.

countermeasure.name: Regularly update to the latest AWS Fargate platform version
countermeasure.desc:
Regularly update your AWS Fargate platform version to benefit from the latest security patches, performance improvements, and new features. Keeping the platform version up-to-date ensures that your Fargate tasks operate securely and efficiently.

Check Current Platform Version:

  • Regularly verify the current platform version of your running Fargate tasks using the AWS Management Console, CLI, or SDK.

Update to Latest Version:

  • Update the task definitions to use the latest Fargate platform version. Ensure that you test the new version in a staging environment before deploying it to production.

Automate Updates:

  • Implement automation tools and scripts to check for new platform versions and update the task definitions accordingly. Use infrastructure as code (IaC) tools like AWS CloudFormation or Terraform to manage updates consistently.

Monitor and Audit:

  • Continuously monitor and audit your Fargate platform versions to ensure they are current. Set up notifications or alerts for new platform version releases.

countermeasure.name: Restrict privileged container access
countermeasure.desc:
Avoid running AWS Fargate tasks with elevated privileges to prevent potential security risks, such as unauthorized access to the host system and privilege escalation. Ensure containers operate with the minimum necessary privileges to maintain a secure environment.

Configure Task Definitions:

  • Define task and container definitions to run without elevated privileges. Ensure the privileged parameter is set to false.

Use Least Privilege Principle:

  • Assign only the necessary permissions and roles required for each container to perform its function, avoiding the use of root or administrative privileges.

Implement Security Policies:

  • Apply IAM roles and policies that restrict access to sensitive resources, ensuring containers can only access what is strictly necessary.

Regular Audits:

  • Conduct regular audits of task and container configurations to verify that none are running with unnecessary privileges. Update configurations as needed to comply with security best practices.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Inadequate resource isolation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Inadequate resource isolation in AWS Fargate can lead to performance issues, security vulnerabilities, and unauthorized access to resources. Ensuring each task and container operates in a dedicated environment is crucial for security and efficiency.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • Malicious insiders
    • External attackers
    • Co-located applications
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting shared memory or CPU resources
    • Misconfigurations in task definitions
    • Container escape vulnerabilities

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized access to data
  • Integrity: Data tampering and corruption
  • Availability: Service disruptions and performance issues
  • Reputation: Loss of trust due to security breaches

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Resource Contention: A task consumes excessive resources, starving other tasks on the same host, leading to performance degradation.
  • Container Escape: An attacker exploits a vulnerability to escape a container and access the underlying host, interfering with other tasks.
  • Cross-Task Access: A malicious insider accesses memory of another task on the same host, exfiltrating sensitive data.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Privileged container access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Privileged container access occurs when containers are run with elevated privileges, allowing them to access the host's resources and potentially leading to security vulnerabilities. Running containers with unnecessary privileges can result in unauthorized access, privilege escalation, and exploitation of the underlying host system.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • Malicious insiders
    • External attackers
    • Compromised applications
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting misconfigured container permissions
    • Leveraging container escape vulnerabilities
    • Accessing host resources through privileged containers

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized access to sensitive data on the host
  • Integrity: Potential tampering with data and system configurations
  • Availability: Service disruptions and resource exhaustion on the host
  • Reputation: Damage to organizational credibility due to security breaches

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Exploiting Misconfigured Permissions: An attacker exploits a container running with root privileges to gain access to the host's file system, allowing them to read, modify, or delete sensitive data.
  • Container Escape Vulnerability: A vulnerability in the container runtime is exploited, allowing an attacker to escape from a privileged container and gain control over the host system, leading to further attacks and data breaches.
  • Accessing Host Resources: A malicious insider uses a privileged container to access and manipulate the host's network interfaces, potentially disrupting network traffic and compromising other containers running on the same host.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1609 - Container Administration Command

threat.name: Outdated platform version
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Using an outdated AWS Fargate platform version can expose applications to known vulnerabilities, lack important security updates, and miss out on performance improvements. Regularly updating to the latest platform version ensures that your tasks benefit from the latest security patches, features, and optimizations provided by AWS.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • External attackers
    • Cybercriminals
    • Malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting known vulnerabilities in older platform versions
    • Leveraging unpatched security flaws
    • Attacking through outdated components and dependencies

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Risk of unauthorized access to sensitive data due to unpatched vulnerabilities.
  • Integrity: Potential for data corruption and unauthorized changes due to security flaws.
  • Availability: Increased likelihood of service disruptions and performance degradation.
  • Reputation: Damage to organizational trust and credibility due to security breaches and compromised performance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Exploiting Known Vulnerabilities: An attacker exploits a known vulnerability in an outdated Fargate platform version to gain unauthorized access to the container environment, leading to data breaches and unauthorized data manipulation.
  • Unpatched Security Flaws: Cybercriminals take advantage of unpatched security flaws in the outdated platform version to execute malicious code, potentially taking control of the container tasks and disrupting service operations.
  • Resource Exhaustion: Due to performance inefficiencies in an outdated platform version, an application experiences resource exhaustion under high load, leading to service downtime and customer dissatisfaction.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted ephemeral storage
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unencrypted ephemeral storage refers to the temporary storage used by AWS Fargate tasks that is not encrypted. This can expose sensitive data to unauthorized access, particularly if the storage is compromised. Ensuring ephemeral storage is encrypted protects data at rest from being accessed or modified by unauthorized entities.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • External attackers
    • Malicious insiders
    • Unauthorized users
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Accessing unencrypted data on compromised ephemeral storage
    • Exploiting vulnerabilities in the Fargate platform to read or alter data
    • Leveraging misconfigured storage permissions

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized access to sensitive data stored temporarily on ephemeral storage.
  • Integrity: Potential tampering with data, leading to corrupted or altered information.
  • Availability: Increased risk of data loss or corruption, affecting application performance and reliability.
  • Reputation: Damage to organizational trust and credibility due to data breaches and security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Data Theft via Compromised Storage: An attacker gains access to a Fargate task's ephemeral storage, which is not encrypted. The attacker reads sensitive data, such as temporary files or logs, leading to a data breach.
  • Data Tampering: A malicious insider with access to ephemeral storage modifies configuration files or data stored temporarily, causing the application to behave unexpectedly or fail.
  • Exploiting Vulnerabilities: Exploiting a vulnerability in the Fargate platform, an attacker accesses unencrypted ephemeral storage, altering or deleting important data, and causing disruption to services.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of container monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

A lack of container monitoring can lead to undetected security incidents, performance issues, and operational inefficiencies in AWS Fargate environments. Without proper monitoring, it becomes challenging to identify and respond to anomalies, potential threats, and resource mismanagement.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • External attackers
    • Malicious insiders
    • Negligent administrators
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting unmonitored vulnerabilities
    • Resource mismanagement due to lack of visibility
    • Undetected malicious activities within containers

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Sensitive data exposure due to unmonitored access and activities
  • Integrity: Potential tampering with data and applications without detection
  • Availability: Service disruptions and degraded performance due to undetected issues
  • Reputation: Loss of customer trust and organizational credibility due to unresolved incidents

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Undetected Resource Misuse: Without monitoring, a compromised container may consume excessive CPU and memory, impacting the performance of other containers and leading to service degradation.
  • Hidden Malware: Malicious code running within an unmonitored container can exfiltrate data or perform harmful actions without detection, leading to data breaches and integrity issues.
  • Unauthorized Access: An attacker gains unauthorized access to a container and performs malicious activities, such as data manipulation or credential theft, which go unnoticed due to the lack of monitoring.

When a certificate is invalid or malicious, it might allow an attacker to spoof a trusted entity by interfering in the communication path between the host and client. The product might connect to a malicious host while believing it is a trusted host, or the product might be deceived into accepting spoofed data that appears to originate from a trusted host.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

countermeasure.name: Disable anonymous authentication
countermeasure.desc:
To prevent unauthenticated access to the Kubernetes API server, it is essential to disable anonymous authentication by setting the --anonymous-auth=false flag. This configuration ensures that requests without credentials are denied, enhancing the security posture of the control plane.

Follow the steps below to implement this security countermeasure:

  1. Locate the configuration file for the API server. This is usually the kube-apiserver.yaml file in the /etc/kubernetes/manifests directory on Kubernetes nodes.
  2. Open the kube-apiserver.yaml file using a text editor, such as vim or nano, for editing. For example:
    sudo vim /etc/kubernetes/manifests/kube-apiserver.yaml
  3. Identify the section that begins with command:. This is where the flags for the API server are specified.
  4. Add or update the --anonymous-auth=false flag in the list of command arguments. Ensure this flag is included as follows:
    command:
    - kube-apiserver
    - --anonymous-auth=false
  5. Save the changes to the kube-apiserver.yaml file and exit the editor.
  6. The Kubernetes API server running in the control plane will automatically detect changes since it is managed as a static pod. Verify that the updated configuration is reflected by inspecting the API server logs:
    kubectl logs -n kube-system $(kubectl get pods -n kube-system --selector=k8s-app=kube-apiserver --output=jsonpath='{.items[0].metadata.name}')
  7. Test the security configuration to ensure that anonymous access has been successfully disabled. Attempt to execute an API request without providing credentials (e.g., using curl) and verify that the request is denied.
  8. Optionally, confirm that authenticated requests still function as expected by using valid credentials with kubectl.

References

  • Kubernetes Documentation: Anonymous Requests

countermeasure.name: Enable and configure audit logging
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure audit events are logged and retained in your Kubernetes environment, follow these steps to configure the `--audit-log-path` parameter along with appropriate retention and size settings:

  1. Modify the kube-apiserver startup configuration:
    • Locate the configuration file or method used to define the startup parameters for `kube-apiserver`. This may involve editing systemd unit files, static YAML manifests, or other deployment methods depending on how your Kubernetes cluster is deployed.
    • Identify or add the `--audit-log-path` flag. This flag specifies the file path where audit logs will be written. Choose a secure and accessible location on the filesystem where sufficient disk space is available.
  2. Configure audit log retention and size settings:
    • Use the `--audit-log-maxage` flag to specify the maximum number of days to retain old audit log files. This ensures logs are cycled and retained according to your organization's data retention policies. For example, `--audit-log-maxage=30` retains logs for 30 days.
    • Use the `--audit-log-maxbackup` flag to define how many old audit log files are kept before being overwritten. For example, `--audit-log-maxbackup=10` keeps up to 10 rotated log files.
    • Use the `--audit-log-maxsize` flag to limit the maximum size (in megabytes) of each audit log file before it is rotated. For example, `--audit-log-maxsize=100` sets a 100MB limit per log file.
  3. Ensure the permissions and ownership for the audit log path are secure:
    • Verify that the directory and file specified by `--audit-log-path` are owned by the `kube-apiserver` process user and are not accessible to unauthorized users or processes.
    • Apply strict file permissions using commands such as chmod and chown to ensure confidentiality of the logs.
  4. Test and validate the configuration:
    • Restart the `kube-apiserver` process or reload its configuration as required by your cluster setup.
    • Generate audit log events by interacting with the Kubernetes API. For example, create, update, or delete resources to ensure auditing is operational.
    • Inspect the log file defined by `--audit-log-path` to confirm events are recorded and verify that the rotation, retention, and size parameters are functioning as expected.
  5. Monitor and regularly review audit logs:
    • Implement log aggregation and monitoring solutions to collect and analyze audit logs centrally. This aids in detecting suspicious activity and maintaining compliance.
    • Schedule periodic reviews of audit log configurations and files to ensure alignment with evolving security and operational needs.

References

  • Kubernetes Audit Logging
