usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers try to gain unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Attackers attempt to bypass authentication mechanisms to gain unauthorized access to the internal server, potentially compromising sensitive data or systems.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers attempting to exploit weak authentication mechanisms or stolen credentials.
  • Internal Attackers: Employees or contractors attempting to access restricted systems without proper authorization.
  • Vectors: Brute-force attacks, stolen credentials, and social engineering.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized System Access: Attackers gain access to sensitive systems or data.
  • Data Loss or Theft: Once inside, attackers can steal or alter critical data.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Brute-Force Attack: Attackers repeatedly attempt to guess passwords to gain access to the server.
  • Phishing Attack: Attackers trick legitimate users into revealing their credentials to access the system.

threat.name: Attackers cause information leakage through misconfigurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Misconfigurations in the system can lead to unintentional exposure of sensitive information to unauthorized parties.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting publicly accessible misconfigurations to gain sensitive data.
  • Internal Attackers: Insiders taking advantage of poor configuration practices.
  • Vectors: Misconfigured file permissions, open ports, or exposed services.

Impacts

  • Exposure of Sensitive Data: Confidential information is unintentionally exposed to unauthorized users.
  • Compliance Violations: Breaching data protection regulations due to improperly configured access controls.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Publicly Accessible Database: A misconfigured database allows unauthorized users to access sensitive records.
  • Misconfigured Cloud Storage: Insecure cloud storage settings lead to exposure of files or credentials.

threat.name: Attackers attempt to steal sensitive data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Attackers target sensitive data stored on the server, attempting to steal or exfiltrate it for malicious purposes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers attempting to breach the server remotely to access confidential information.
  • Internal Attackers: Employees or contractors misusing their access to steal data.
  • Vectors: Exploiting vulnerabilities, phishing, or improper access controls.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Sensitive information such as customer data or proprietary information is exposed or stolen.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust from customers and partners due to the breach.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Phishing Attack: Attackers trick employees into revealing login credentials, granting access to sensitive data.
  • Data Exfiltration: Exploiting vulnerabilities to copy or transfer sensitive files to an external server.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers gain physical unauthorized access to the server
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Attackers gain physical access to the server hardware, potentially allowing them to tamper with, steal, or damage the system and its data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Intruders attempting to bypass physical security to gain direct access to the server.
  • Internal Attackers: Employees or contractors misusing access privileges to physically compromise the server.
  • Vectors: Breaking into data centers, stealing server hardware, or gaining access to secure facilities.

Impacts

  • Data Theft: Physical access can lead to direct theft of sensitive data or hardware.
  • System Tampering: Attackers can alter system configurations or install malware, compromising server integrity.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Data Center Break-In: Attackers infiltrate the data center and steal a server containing sensitive information.
  • Unauthorized Server Access: An employee with physical access installs malicious software on a server, bypassing network defenses.

threat.name: Attackers deploy malware to compromise the system
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Attackers introduce malicious software (malware) into the system to exploit vulnerabilities, gain control, or cause damage.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Cybercriminals deploying malware through phishing emails, malicious downloads, or remote exploitation.
  • Internal Attackers: Insiders introducing malware to disrupt operations or steal data.
  • Vectors: Phishing, drive-by downloads, or exploiting software vulnerabilities.

Impacts

  • System Compromise: Malware can allow attackers to control the system, steal data, or spread across the network.
  • Data Corruption: Malware may corrupt or delete critical data, disrupting business operations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Phishing Email with Ransomware: Attackers send a malicious email attachment that installs ransomware upon opening.
  • Exploiting Unpatched Software: Attackers exploit an unpatched vulnerability to install a backdoor Trojan.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-327
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-327: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm The product uses a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm or protocol.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

Configure both phases of the Internet Key Exchange (IKE) to utilize AES-256-GCM for maximum security during the VPN handshake and data transfer processes. Regularly review and update the VPN configuration to ensure compatibility with security best practices and evolving encryption standards.

Regularly review the key exchange settings and upgrade to more secure groups as they become available to maintain a strong security posture.

threat.name: Unrestricted VPN traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unrestricted VPN traffic occurs when VPN tunnels are configured to allow all traffic without filtering, exposing the network to unnecessary risks. Without proper traffic controls, malicious actors or unauthorized users could gain access to sensitive resources and perform unauthorized actions within the network.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Attackers or unauthorized users could exploit the open access provided by unrestricted VPN traffic. Common vectors include brute-force attacks, lateral movement within the network, or malware that utilizes the VPN tunnel for data exfiltration.

Impacts

Unrestricted VPN traffic can lead to unauthorized access to critical systems, data breaches, malware infections, and compliance violations. The lack of granular control increases the attack surface, making the network more vulnerable to internal and external threats.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: A user gains VPN access but can reach more sensitive parts of the network than intended due to an overly permissive VPN configuration.
  • Scenario 2: An attacker compromises a user's credentials and uses the VPN to explore and escalate privileges within the network, accessing sensitive data or launching further attacks.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Vulnerable IKE negotiation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Vulnerable Internet Key Exchange (IKE) negotiations occur when weak or outdated versions of the IKE protocol are used to establish a VPN connection. IKE vulnerabilities can be exploited during the VPN tunnel setup, leading to interception of key exchanges or man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, compromising the security of the VPN connection.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include attackers exploiting weaknesses in IKE versions, such as IKEv1, which is prone to known vulnerabilities. Attack vectors include intercepting IKE messages, brute-forcing Diffie-Hellman key exchanges, or manipulating the session to gain unauthorized access to the VPN.

Impacts

Successful exploitation of vulnerable IKE negotiations can lead to compromised VPN connections, interception of sensitive data, unauthorized access, or the ability to decrypt VPN traffic. This could result in data breaches, loss of confidentiality, and potential regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker intercepts IKEv1 negotiations and exploits known vulnerabilities to access the VPN traffic and gain unauthorized access to the network.
  • Scenario 2: During the IKE phase, an attacker uses a weak Diffie-Hellman group to compromise the key exchange, allowing them to decrypt sensitive data transmitted over the VPN.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1196 - Control Panel Items

threat.name: Inadequate key exchange mechanisms
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Inadequate key exchange mechanisms occur when weak or outdated cryptographic algorithms, such as low-strength Diffie-Hellman (DH) groups, are used during VPN negotiations. These vulnerabilities can compromise the security of the VPN, allowing attackers to intercept or decrypt key exchanges, resulting in unauthorized access to sensitive data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Attackers could exploit weaknesses in key exchange mechanisms by leveraging brute-force attacks, intercepting Diffie-Hellman key exchanges, or exploiting known vulnerabilities in outdated Internet Key Exchange (IKE) configurations. The use of weak DH groups or older IKE versions (e.g., IKEv1) exposes the system to cryptographic attacks.

Impacts

If the key exchange is compromised, attackers can potentially decrypt traffic, gain unauthorized access to encrypted data, or even impersonate trusted systems, leading to significant security breaches, data exposure, and non-compliance with security regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker takes advantage of a VPN tunnel using a low-strength Diffie-Hellman group to compromise the key exchange and decrypt sensitive data transmitted over the VPN.
  • Scenario 2: A network administrator uses an outdated IKE version (IKEv1) with known vulnerabilities, allowing an attacker to manipulate the key exchange and gain unauthorized access to encrypted communications.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1032 - Standard Cryptographic Protocol

threat.name: Insecure VPN tunnels
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure VPN tunnels occur when weak encryption or misconfigurations leave data transmitted between on-premises systems and AWS vulnerable to interception or decryption.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Attackers may exploit outdated encryption protocols, such as weak Diffie-Hellman groups, or use man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks to intercept or alter VPN traffic.

Impacts

Sensitive data exposure, unauthorized access to the network, and potential data breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker exploits weak encryption in a VPN tunnel to intercept confidential communications.
  • Scenario 2: An outdated IKE version is compromised, allowing unauthorized access to encrypted data.

threat.name: Unmonitored VPN traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unmonitored VPN traffic occurs when there is insufficient logging or monitoring of data being transmitted over the AWS Site-to-Site VPN. Without proper oversight, suspicious or malicious activities, such as unauthorized access or data exfiltration, can go undetected, potentially leading to data breaches or network compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers leveraging weaknesses in the VPN configuration, or insiders transmitting unauthorized traffic. Attack vectors may include attempts to bypass security controls, malware using VPN traffic to exfiltrate data, or unauthorized access due to lack of traffic inspection.

Impacts

Undetected security incidents, unauthorized access, and data breaches, leading to financial loss, legal repercussions, and reputational damage. Organizations may fail to meet compliance requirements that mandate monitoring of sensitive traffic.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: A malware-infected device uses the VPN tunnel to exfiltrate data. Without monitoring in place, the malicious activity remains undetected.
  • Scenario 2: An unauthorized user gains access to the VPN but remains unnoticed due to a lack of real-time traffic monitoring, allowing lateral movement within the network.
